title: ATAC-seq on Sorted Adult Mouse Neurons
procedures: Procedure Overview Harvest and section brain tissue (1-2 h depending on the number of mice).Micro dissection and tissue digestion (1-1.5 h).Trituration and Percoll separation (1-1.5 h depending on the amount of tissue).Sorting (variable depending on machine and sample size, typically more than 2 h).Preparing nuclei and tagmentation (~1 h).Pause point: Tagmented nuclei can be stored at -20 °C for up to two weeks. Library preparation (2-3 h depending on the number of samples).Pause point: Amplified DNA can be stored at -20 °C. Quality assessment (2-3 h).Harvest and Section Brain Tissue Add the following reagents to Cutting Solution (CS) and Modified Artificial Cerebral Spinal Fluid (mACSF):Ketamine (0.05 mM final concentration) or 0.05 mM APVTTX (100 nM final concentration) Kynurenic acid (0.8 mM final concentration) or 0.02 mM DNQXNotes:These inhibitors are important for high quality ATAC from neurons. They prevent excitotoxicity as tissue is sliced and dissociated. The amount of CS and mACSF needed will depend on the number and size of animals perfused and the set-up used. For reference, when perfusing four young adult mice typically weighing ~20 mg, 300 ml of CS and 100 ml of mACSF are prepared. If working with a cell type that requires multiple rounds of Percoll centrifugation (Step 26), extra mACSF may be needed. Prior to attempting the protocol, we recommend calculating the volume needed by measuring and summing the volumes of liquid needed for each step. To allow for the possibility of poor perfusions requiring additional volume (Step 4d), prepare 50 ml extra of CS. To mACSF, add 5% (w/v) Trehalose.Note: This is a protectant for tissue dissociation (Saxena et al., 2012). The effects of Trehalose are a bit controversial (Lee et al., 2018), but we found it increases the number of intact neurons after trituration.

Stir at room temp (RT) and oxygenate using gas diffuser until Kynurenic acid dissolves.Note: mACSF can remain at room temp.Move enough CS to a new container to oxygenate and suspend one or more cell strainers.Place container in a water bath at 34 °C.After sectioning, brain slices will recover at 34 °C (Ting et al., 2014).Move remaining CS to 4 °C and oxygenate.Harvest brain.Make an ice bath around the vibratome buffer tray.Fill vibratome buffer tray with cold CS and oxygenate.Administer lethal dose of appropriate anesthetic.Ideally before heart stops beating, perfuse cold CS via trans-cardiac perfusion through the left ventricle exiting the right atrium until blood has been completely replaced with CS and tissues such as the liver and lungs are no longer red (Typically 20-30 ml depending on mouse size). If the liver has red patches this indicates poor perfusion of tissues. Continue perfusing until the liver color is evenly white/tan and only clear CS is seen exiting the heart. For a detailed example of trans-cardiac perfusion technique see Gage et al. (2012).Quickly remove brain and place in oxygenating CS filled vibratome buffer tray. Note: For dissection details, see Papouin and Haydon (2018).If slicing multiple brains repeat (c)-(f) for each animal.Make sure brain(s) in tray do not come in direct contact with O2 bubbles.Allow the last brain to equilibrate for 5 min.Mount brains for slicing.Place wet blot paper with oxygenated cold CS inside a 100-mm petri dish.Place brain(s) on wetted paper.Remove unwanted tissue and cut to create a flat surface to affix the brain.Examples of two options for mounting the brain are shown in Video 1. The first brain is mounted by removing the cerebellum so that rostral structures will be sliced first. The second brain is oriented in the opposite direction so that caudal structures may be sliced.

Both orientations will produce coronal slices.Use a fine scalpel to minimize tissue distortion that can damage neurons. [href=http://www.bio-protocol.org/e3382]

Video 1. Mounting brains on vibratome platform. (Animal experimentation: All experiments were conducted in accordance with the requirements of the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committees at Brandeis University (protocol #17001).) Attach brains to platform with Loctite. Affix the brain in an orientation such that cells of interest are away from the Loctite.Move platform back to oxygenated CS. Note: There is no need to wait for Loctite to air dry.Micro Dissection and Tissue Digestion Slice mounted brain(s) into 300 µm sections through the region of interest.Set speed to 3 (on a scale of 0-10) and frequency between 6 and 8 (on a scale of 0-10). Note: Settings should be optimized on individual equipment to minimize tissue distortion/compression. If brains tend to come loose during slicing, then the speed may be too fast or the frequency too low. Reducing tissue deformation/compression will increase yield. We recommend always using a fresh blade.Using a wide mouth pipette or a plastic transfer pipette that has been cut to make the opening larger gently move slices to cell strainers in oxygenated CS at 34 °CThe strainer protects slices from coming into direct contact with oxygenation bubbles.If working with cells expressing a fluorescent marker, protect samples from light as much as possible from here on to minimize photobleaching.Incubate for 10-12 min.Move strainer containing slices to oxygenated mACSF at RT.Ensure slices are submerged.Allow equilibrating for 5-10 min.Dissolve pronase (10% w/v) in RT oxygenated mACSF (20-40 ml) and pour into a 100 mm petri dish.Transfer the strainer with slices to Petri dish with pronase solution. Use a wide mouth pipette or cut plastic transfer pipette to move slices from the strainer and into the solution. Incubate for 1-1.

5 h at RT.While slices digest, micro-dissect region(s) of interest under a stereomicroscope.If dissecting a large number of slices, it is ideal to work in batches using several dishes so that the tissue waiting to be dissected or post-dissection can be oxygenated in the pronase solution.When finished dissection, oxygenate tissue pieces in pronase solution for any remaining time on the digest incubation.This step should be optimized to reduce non-target tissue. Enriching the cells of interest will reduce flow cytometry sort times.Prepare 30-50 ml of oxygenated mACSF + 1% FBS (mACSF + FBS), filter with Steriflip and keep on iceAdd 1 U/ml DNase to 5-10 ml of filtered mACSF + FBS (mACSF + FBS + DNase), keep on ice.Move tissue pieces to 1 ml of mACSF + FBS.Wash tissue 2-3 x with mACSF + FBS to quench and remove protease by allowing tissue to settle to the bottom of the tube and removing most of the supernatant. Add fresh mACSF + FBS and repeat. Suspend tissue pieces in mACSF + FBS + DNase and divide between Eppendorf tubes such that the volume of tissue does not exceed 0.1% of the volume (Figure 1).Notes: DNase prevents genomic DNA released by lysed cells from clumping and blocking the pipette opening during trituration. Trituration with too dense cell solution results in low yield of live cells.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190928/20190928063828_3524.jpgFigure 1. Example of tissue amount for trituration in 1 mlKeep tissue on ice.With the 600 μm fire-polished Pasteur pipette, gently triturate the sample ten times.Pre-wet the pipette to prevent tissue from sticking to the inside walls.Avoid making bubbles as this can damage cells.The pipette mouth should not be held against the wall or floor of the tube.The solution should turn cloudy with large chunks remaining.Incubate tube(s) on ice allowing chunks to settle for a few minutes.

Filter supernatant using tube with cell strainer cap.Note: You may need to prewet the strainer with mACSF + FBS to start gravity flow. Add 1 ml fresh mACSF + FBS + DNase I to remaining tissue chunks.Note: If working with precious small amounts of tissues, rinse the cell strainer cap with the 1 ml and transfer any chunks left in the top back to the Eppendorf for the next trituration step. Triturate ten times with the 400 μm fire-polished Pasteur pipette as described in Step 17.Note: The solution should become cloudy again, and remaining chunks be smaller. Filter supernatants (as in step 19) into the same tube and add fresh mACSF + FBS + DNase (as in Step 20).Trituration and Percoll Separation Triturate ten times with the 200 μm fire-polished Pasteur pipette. Again, filter supernatant into the same tube.If chunks remain you may repeat the 200 μm trituration on leftover chunks.Transfer the combined, filtered cell suspension to a 15 ml falcon tube.Centrifuge at 4 °C through a Percoll solution. Always load ~25 μl of 100% Percoll at the bottom of the tube underneath the Percoll solution to act as a cushion for your cell pellet. Note: This step should be optimized for the cell type of interest. The goal is to separate cell bodies from smaller debris to make sorting more efficient. We proved example conditions from three types of neurons that are small, medium, and large in size for guidance in optimizing. Example conditionsPercoll solutionFor cerebellar Purkinje neurons, which are large, the cell suspension was brought to a final concentration of 5% (v/v) Percoll in 5-10 ml.For cortical pyramidal neurons, the cell suspension was brought to a final concentration of 10% (v/v) Percoll in 5-10 ml.

For cerebellar granule neurons, which are small, the cell suspension was brought to a final concentration of 20% (v/v) Percoll in 5-10 ml.CentrifugationFor cerebellar Purkinje neurons in 10 ml, 54 x g for 15 min is used.For cortical pyramidal neurons in 10 ml, 54 x g for 15 min is used.For cerebellar granule neurons in 10 ml, 91 x g for 20 min is used.Note: The first cerebellar granule cell pellet typically contains too much debris. To clean it up further the pellet is resuspended in another 5 ml of 20% Percoll, and centrifuged again. When optimizing, move the supernatant to a new tube and keep on ice.~25 μl of the supernatant can be placed on slide or small dish. Once cells have settled for 1-2 min the droplet can be examined under a fluorescent microscope to estimate the number of cell bodies that failed to pellet.If needed, you may add a Percoll cushion to the bottom of the tube containing the supernatant and centrifuge again. This typically results in a pellet with additional cells, but often contains more debris than the first pellet.ConsiderationsPelleting cell bodies through the Percoll solution is a balance between speed, time, the concentration of Percoll (and volume, to lesser degree). Less force and less time spent centrifuging typically produced higher quality samples. Optimize for the minimal Percoll concentration that removes enough debris to significantly shorten sorting on the flow cytometer. It is not necessary to fully fractionate the sample.An additional option is to layer the cell suspension on top of the Percoll solution. This has the disadvantage of making it difficult to do additional spins on the supernatant but may allow better fractionation of some samples.Suspend cell pellet in 1-3 ml cold mACSF + FBS immediately after removing supernatant.

Note: Avoid leaving cells pelleted for long periods of time. Filter through a clean tube with cell strainer cap.Sorting Sort on a flow cytometerDuring optimization we recommend sorting ~100 cells onto a slide or small dish and examine the droplet under a fluorescent microscope to confirm cells of interest were isolated and estimate debris contamination using fluorescent illumination and brightfield. Gating strategies are highly cell type and flow cytometer dependent. The goal is to capture individual healthy cells containing high levels of fluorescence signal. Our gates typically capture the top 1-10% of fluorescent events and subset to capture events with side scatter and forward scatter indicative of single cells and excluding doublets/clumps and debris.Adding a small amount of DNA dye such as Hoechst be useful in distinguishing small cell bodies containing a nucleus from debris when working with small neurons such as granule cells.Notes: Hoechst will penetrate live cells. If using other dyes such as DAPI or propidium iodide Triton x 100 will need to be added to permeabilize cells. With the bright mCitrine+ cells from Nelson enhancer trap lines (Shima et al., 2016) we often observe cell lysis under the microscope. A cell becomes dim and the fluorescent protein can be seen diffusing away. Therefore, simply estimating the number of cells that lack fluorescence by eye as a measure of contamination would likely give an overestimate and should not be used for this purpose. Sort bulk samples into a tube containing cold mACSF + FBS.Optional: to increase the quality of difficult samples tagment the sample in ~10,000 cell batches.For this, collect ~10,000 cells and follow Steps 29-39 while the next batch of cells is collected. Scale the tagmentation reaction in Step 36 by 1/5.Batching the sample reduces the overall time early sorted cells sit in suspension.

Batches can be pooled later for library prep as needed, prioritizing batches collected earlier in the sort as these tended to give higher quality ATAC.Pellet sorted cells at 4 °C.Centrifuge sorted cells at 500 x g for 2 min.Rotate tube 180° in holder, centrifuge again at 700 x g for 1 min.Rotate tube 180° again and centrifuge at 500 x g for 2 min.Note: Alternating the force angle helps collect cells off the tube wall and reduces cell loss when removing the supernatant. The pellet is often not visible for samples < 20,000 cells.Preparing Nuclei and Tagmentation Solution Remove the supernatant leaving ~2 μl and immediately resuspend the cell pellet by gentle flicking.Add 100 μl of Lysis Buffer and mix gently.Incubate on ice for 2-5 min.Note: The goal is to lyse the cell membrane while leaving the nucleus mostly intact. Quench lysis by diluting with 1 ml of mACSF+FBS.This reduces the concentration of Triton X-100 allowing 2-3 μl to be left behind at Step 37 without inhibiting tagmentation later on.Pellet nuclei at 4 °C.Centrifuge nuclei at 700 x g for 2 min.Rotate tube 180°, centrifuge at 1,000 x g for 1 min.Rotate tube 180°, centrifuge at 700 x g for 2 min.The pellet is often not visible for samples < 40,000 nuclei.Prepare 1x tagmentation solution:For 50,000 cells:table:

Pause point: Sample can be stored at -20 °C for up to two weeks.Library Preparation If starting from frozen samples, allow samples to warm to room temp.Purify tagmented DNA.Load and wash columns according to Zymo kit instructions.Elute in a volume to obtain ~2,500 cells worth of material/μl.Note: ~1 μl is typically not recovered from the column. Therefore, an extra 1 μl can be added when calculating volumes. To increase recovery of DNA from the column the volume can be split between two elutions.For example, 40,000 cells worth of tagmented material can be eluted in 8.5 μl twice to give ~16 μl total.

The kit recommends using a minimum volume of 6 μl for elution. For samples where two 6 μl elutions would dilute the sample below 2,500 cells/μl, elute 2 times with 6 μl using H2O or diluted EB buffer* and rotovap to concentrate to ~2,500 cells worth of material/μl.*1x EB buffer comes with the Zymo DNA Clean kit. Dilute with H2O such that it will be 1x in the target final volume after rotovap concentration. For example, if the target final volume is 6 μl, rotovaping will concentrate the sample that was eluted twice with 6 μl by 2-fold, so a 1:2 dilution is needed.Prepare PCR Amplification Mix.For 50,000 cells worth of material :table:

Note: If final libraries contain significant primer dimer contamination, the primer concentration can be cut in half. Add PCR Amplification Mix to the tube containing eluted DNA, mix by pipetting up and down 5-10 times then transfer to appropriate PCR tube(s) for amplification.Notes: The original ATAC and Omni-ATAC protocols suggest amplifying a small fraction of the sample in a qPCR thermocycler to determine the optimal number of PCR cycles and then amplify the rest of the sample in a different thermocycler appropriate for the larger volume. We found the optimal number of cycles varied for a single master mix aliquoted in different volumes as well as between different thermocyclers. To ensure the whole sample was amplified optimally and consistently, the entire sample was amplified in a qPCR thermocycler and monitored in real time to observe which cycle the fluorescent signal began to increase. Therefore, depending on the machine and sample volume, it may be necessary to divide the sample between multiple tubes. Aliquot the sample into the minimum number of PCR tubes (to reduce sample loss) without exceeding the recommended maximum volume for the qPCR machine. Stop the amplification 2-3 cycles after the fluorescent signal begins to rise. Notes:Good quality libraries typically show an increase in fluorescent signal in < 6 cycles. Libraries that require > 12 cycles typically have low complexity. Note: The 2x NEBNext Master Mix is sensitive to freeze thaw cycles. Best practice is to aliquot, store in an enzyme box, and protect from temperature swings while in the freezer. We recommend tracking the number of cycles need for libraries over time. If cycles creep up over batches, it may indicate the need to replace 2x Master Mix and further optimize storage.If obtaining ATAC libraries with a large fraction of PCR duplicates (e.g., > 50%), reduce the number of cycles by 1. Purify amplified libraries using Zymo DNA Clean and Concentrator-5 Kit.Pool replicate tubes from the same sample.Optional: If concerned about yield, rinse PCR tubes with DNA Binding Buffer.Elute in 6 μl of low TE twice (total volume will be ~11 μl).Quality Assessment Move 1 μl to a new tube and dilute 1:2 with low TE. Use this aliquot for quality control testing and quantification.Run 1 μl on a High Sensitivity Bioanalyzer Chip to examine the size distribution of fragments Note: Figure 2A shows examples of the size distribution diversity from libraries that gave high quality sequencing data. While nucleosome laddering can indicate a high-quality library, good libraries do not always have this pattern. Use 0.5 μl for qPCR with primers against genomic regions as in Table 2.Notes:Libraries with low complexity may show strong signal from 1-2 TSS regions but lack signal at 1-2 other TSS regions. High quality libraries typically showed strong signal from at least 3 different TSS regions. Libraries with good signal to noise at open regions typically gave a mean (TSS): mean (background) ratio > 50.

This ratio may need to be established empirically if using other regions, species or tissue types.  Use 0.5 μl to quantify using Kapa Library Quantification Kit according to manufacturer’s instructions. Unique non-mitochondrial reads per million from the samples in A. Transcription start site (TSS) enrichment calculated following ENCODE guidelines for all seven samples was ≥ 20. Examples are from multiple different cell types.Store the remaining 10 μl at -20 °C until sequenced.Sequence libraries.The protocol used for sequencing depends on the project goals. Paired-end sequencing is most commonly used with ATAC. This provides data on the total length of the fragment generated by transposition. Filtering data for certain sized fragments can be useful for certain analyses.When considering fragments versus reads it is important to keep in mind that the ends of fragments or one end of a read represents the location of Tn5 access to the genome while the fragment itself is the intervening DNA between two transposition events.
